scroller.text: For decades, U.S. soybeans fed China’s growing demand, binding the two economies together. The share of U.S. soybeans going to China climbed from under 40% in the mid-2000s to nearly 60% by 2011, making China America’s most important agricultural customer.
scroller.detail: Two main corridors carry U.S. soybeans to China: Pacific Northwest shipments take a direct trans-Pacific track, while Gulf exports move through the Panama Canal to ports in southern China.

scroller.text: Since 2013, China has invested in more than 23 Latin American seaports, building a logistics network to support its growing trade with the region.
scroller.detail: These seaport investments range from multi-billion-dollar deep-water terminals to smaller upgrades that improve rail links, storage capacity, and ship turnaround times.

scroller.text: The partnership between the U.S. and China began to crumble in 2018, when tariffs during President Trump’s first term triggered a sharp drop in U.S. soybean sales to China. Brazil quickly filled the gap and has remained China’s top soybean supplier ever since.

Since President Trump returned to the White House in January 2025, tensions with China have flared again, hitting the U.S. soybean industry hard. Beijing has responded by largely shutting its doors to American soybeans and deepening ties with Latin American suppliers, especially Brazil.
One of China’s most strategic port investments is the Port of Santos, on Brazil’s southeastern coast.
There, China’s state-owned company Cofco cemented its presence after winning a 2022 concession to modernize and expand the STS11 agricultural terminal.
The Port of Santos is Brazil’s main gateway for foreign trade, handling nearly one-third of the country’s total trade flow. About half of those exports go to China, mainly soybeans.

On Peru’s Pacific coast, China has invested in the Port of Chancay. Developed by another Chinese state-owned company, Cosco, (60%) and Peru’s Volcan Compañía Minera (40%), the $3.4 billion project marks a major expansion of China’s Belt and Road Initiative into Latin America.
From Chancay, ships can reach China faster than they can through the Atlantic coast or other northern ports on the continent.
scroller.detail: A direct Pacific route from Chancay reaches China faster—around 25 days—while the older Panama-Canal route can take 30–35 days.

scroller.text: The port is designed to move one million containers annually in its first phase. It could reshape Pacific trade, carrying not only Peru’s copper and blueberries, but also Brazil’s soybeans and other products from Latin America.
While this is all happening in South America, it’s also affecting farmers in the U.S.
